facts.fact: Kaspa's Crescendo achieves a 6000x improvement over Satoshi’s protocol while maintaining the same trust model.
facts.context: This improvement refers to scalability and/or performance enhancements in Kaspa over Bitcoin, while preserving a decentralized, trust-minimized architecture with anonymous miners.

source.title: In which we are all faceless until we have faces (Part I)*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: Kaspa’s trust model is center-less, delegating control over the network to an anonymous set of miners.
facts.context: This affirms that Kaspa’s protocol is designed to operate without a central authority, relying on anonymous miners whose incentives are aligned with network security.

source.title: In which we are all faceless until we have faces (Part I)*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: The primary social media account for Kaspa was renamed from “Kaspa” to “Kaspa (Unofficial)”.
facts.context: This action reflects a move to reinforce Kaspa’s decentralized and center-less ethos, reducing the influence or perception of official centralized control.

source.title: In which we are all faceless until we have faces (Part I)*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: Kaspa positions itself as a p2p electronic cash system and a trustworthy store of value, aiming to compete in the broader crypto and financial markets.
facts.context: This establishes Kaspa’s technical ambition to occupy a similar user and value proposition space as Bitcoin.

source.title: In which we are all faceless until we have faces (Part I)*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: The arrival of ASIC miners is anticipated for the Kaspa network and is considered an overall positive development, even for existing GPU miners.
facts.context: The introduction of ASICs will increase the capital expenditure (CapEx) required for mining, contributing to the network’s security and signifying a maturing ecosystem.

facts.fact: Kaspa currently has about 5.3% of its network hashrate available for rent via NiceHash.
facts.context: The low proportion of NiceHash-able hashrate means the mining market is still relatively illiquid, reducing vulnerability to 51% attacks based on rented hashrate.

facts.fact: Kaspa’s consensus layer prioritizes speed of confirmation, with secondary goals including increased throughput capacity and decentralization, and plans for MEV resistance in the future.
facts.context: Focusing on fast confirmations and scalability helps Kaspa compete as a next-generation blockchain, while MEV resistance is important for fairness and long-term integrity.

facts.fact: Kaspa’s model emphasizes moving toward CapEx-heavy (ASIC-dominated) mining for security and efficiency.
facts.context: CapEx-heavy mining makes it economically harder for attackers to rent large amounts of temporary hashrate, thereby increasing network security and energy efficiency.

facts.fact: CapEx-heavy mining is more energy efficient because a smaller fraction of the network’s security budget is consumed with each new block produced.
facts.context: Improved energy efficiency is critical for addressing concerns about Proof-of-Work mining’s environmental and political viability, especially as Kaspa plans for mass adoption.

facts.fact: For Kaspa, virtually instantaneous confirmation times in a permissionless consensus require a CapEx-heavy (ASIC-dominated) mining environment.
facts.context: Instant confirmation times are only sustainable if the mining market is illiquid (mostly CapEx), reducing 51% attack risks and aligning with Kaspa’s aims for fast, secure transactions.

facts.fact: In Kaspa, capital expenditure (CapEx)—rather than operational expenditure (OpEx, e.g., GPU mining)—is being positioned as the dominant cost in mining’s future.
facts.context: High CapEx entry requirements reduce the ability for attackers to cheaply influence network consensus, increasing network resilience.

facts.fact: DAGKNIGHT (DK) is a protocol developed by Yonatan Sompolinsky and Sutton, intended for integration with Kaspa, and its main technical TODOs are detailed in KIP #2.
facts.context: Introducing and implementing the DAGKNIGHT protocol is a major consensus and performance upgrade for Kaspa, and KIP #2 formally documents the steps needed.

facts.fact: The previous community-funded development grant for Kaspa was 100 million KAS (MKAS), equivalent to approximately 1% of the then circulating supply.
facts.context: Establishes a precedent for the scale of funding given to core protocol upgrades via community consensus.

facts.fact: A new development grant proposal for implementing DAGKNIGHT on Kaspa has been submitted, requesting 70 MKAS (~0.5% of circulating supply).
facts.context: This mirrors the funding approach used for KAS protocol development, reflecting ongoing use of on-chain/in-community funding for major network upgrades.

facts.fact: The development and release of Kaspa mainnet by DAGlabs was done without a premine, heads-up on mining, founders' rewards, or similar incentives.
facts.context: This highlights the protocol’s launch — notable for its absence of private or early allocation, meaning all coins were publicly mined from genesis.

facts.fact: The timeline and completion of DAGKNIGHT integration on Kaspa are not strictly dependent on grant approval: the protocol authors intend to implement it regardless, but formal grant funding would accelerate development.
facts.context: If the grant is not approved by the community, progress on DAGKNIGHT may be slower or completed on a non-specific timeline, potentially affecting upgrade timing.

facts.fact: The DAGKNIGHT (DK) protocol, published by Michal Sutton and Yonatan Sompolinsky, claims to be the first Proof-of-Work (PoW) consensus protocol that is responsive to the network’s actual adversarial latency while being resilient to 49% Byzantine attackers.
facts.context: This represents a new design in PoW consensus, offering improved security and responsiveness under real network conditions.

facts.fact: DK enables high blocks-per-second (bps) like Kaspa’s existing GHOSTDAG but provides much faster confirmation times.
facts.context: Improved confirmation time can significantly enhance user experience and transaction finality in high-throughput blockchain environments.

facts.fact: Further research is necessary to determine the optimal blocks-per-second for DK, as increasing block rates may widen the DAG and increase block header size, potentially offsetting confirmation time improvements.
facts.context: Tuning block rates is critical for network performance and efficiency.

facts.fact: The current DK pseudocode is highly inefficient and must be refined for real-world implementation, focusing on devising efficient algorithms.
facts.context: Practical deployment requires the protocol to be computationally and resource efficient.

facts.fact: The DK protocol must be adapted to manage cryptocurrency-specific requirements such as minting regulation, difficulty control, and pruning, which require a responsive synchronous protocol, instead of DK’s current partially synchronous operation mode.
facts.context: Without these adaptations, DK cannot be deployed as a working consensus mechanism for cryptocurrencies like Kaspa.

facts.fact: DK uniquely supports features such as flexcaps, allowing miners to create blocks with variable sizes and difficulties without predefined DAG width constraints.
facts.context: Flexcaps can help handle peak demand by temporarily increasing throughput, which is challenging in other protocols due to DAG width requirements.

facts.fact: DK’s protocol asynchrony in high bps environments could be utilized to enhance privacy (via stealth transactions) and reduce Miner Extractable Value (MEV), supporting advanced fee mechanisms similar to those proposed by Flashbots’ SUAVE.
facts.context: These features could make the protocol more resilient to front-running and other MEV-related behaviors, enhancing user security and privacy.

facts.fact: Completing DK’s formal proof, paper for peer-review, and efficient implementation are prerequisites before the protocol is considered for inclusion in Kaspa.
facts.context: Academic scrutiny and technical readiness are essential before any consensus upgrade.

facts.fact: Any consensus upgrade (such as implementing DK) will require a new grant proposal to the Kaspa community, similar to the recent Rust upgrade.
facts.context: Community governance and funding are necessary for coordinating and implementing major protocol changes.

facts.fact: One of Kaspa’s core developers, Michael Sutton, proposed refactoring the Kaspad full-node codebase and rewriting it in Rust to significantly enhance performance.
facts.context: Transitioning to Rust is expected to improve modularity, code legibility, and potentially order-of-magnitude performance increases for Kaspa nodes.

facts.fact: The current Kaspad codebase is an adaptation of the Bitcoin client btcd and is written in Golang.
facts.context: The inherited structure leads to technical debt and code complexity, making contributions difficult for new developers.

facts.fact: The proposed refactor aims to make the codebase more modular and easier to understand, beyond just improving performance.
facts.context: Improved structure and readability can enhance community contribution and the maintainability of the project.

facts.fact: Kaspa was initially launched as a live demonstration of a novel permissionless consensus paradigm.
facts.context: The project's primary goal was to showcase new consensus concepts, influencing design and development priorities.

facts.fact: Kaspa was originally released in a "gamenet" mode, described as "testnet with incentives."
facts.context: This launch mode provided real-world testing conditions with incentivized participation, influencing network reliability and growth.

facts.fact: Kaspa’s development and treasury are managed by a small group of volunteers, and the treasury is contribution-based.
facts.context: The limited resources affect the rate and direction of development, including decisions about major technical undertakings like a Rust rewrite.

facts.fact: The random block reward has been removed; Kaspa now uses a deterministic block reward of 500 Kaspa per block.
facts.context: Simplifies logic and debugging; ensures predictable daily mining rewards of 43,200,000 Kaspa.

facts.fact: A rebase of Kaspa is planned, which will be cosmetic only (a renaming/altering of representation) and will not affect user balances or proportional ownership.
facts.context: Users' percentage ownership of total or circulating supply will remain unchanged after the rebase.

facts.fact: A deflationary monetary policy hard fork (HF) is planned and will be specified the week after network syncing and mining resume.
facts.context: The upcoming HF will impact Kaspa’s monetary policy; details to be released after network stabilization.

facts.fact: For network recovery after the crash, the team sought the latest state with a certainly-valid UTXO commitment, not an arbitrary rollback to an old state.
facts.context: This approach ensures the preservation of valid transaction history and UTXO set continuity.

facts.fact: The UTXO commitment obtained during network recovery matched the commitment in the latest block, specifically hash 710f27df423e63aa6cdb72b89ea5a06cffa399d66f167704455b5af59def8e20.
facts.context: Validates that the DAG UTXO algebra remained correct, confirming integrity of the ledger after the recovery attempt.

facts.fact: The network crash was attributed to a memory problem, not to an error in the DAG UTXO algebra.
facts.context: Indicates that the underlying design is sound but susceptible to infrastructure issues, suggesting need for module architecture improvements.

facts.fact: Kaspa's monetary policy will be deflationary, with a halving schedule that is more aggressive than Bitcoin's.
facts.context: Aggressive deflationary schedules directly impact coin supply, scarcity, and long-term economic incentives for miners and holders.

facts.fact: The initial block reward and activation timing for the deflationary schedule are still to be determined, with decisions likely in the following week.
facts.context: The specific numbers for initial rewards and schedule will determine mining incentives and emission rates.

facts.fact: Kaspa uses a custom proof-of-work algorithm: a Kaspa variant of heavy-hash, referred to as "k-heavy-hash."
facts.context: Choice of proof-of-work impacts hardware compatibility, security, and energy consumption.

facts.fact: "k-heavy-hash" is designed to be CapEx heavy, aiming for energy efficiency and greater miner commitment.
facts.context: CapEx heavy algorithms aim to reduce operational costs and encourage longer-term investment in mining infrastructure.

facts.fact: Kaspa's development is maintained by a small number of part-time developers, some funded by DAGlabs, with no formal company or overarching entity behind the project.
facts.context: Project governance and decentralization can affect development speed, security, and community trust.

facts.fact: Near-term development priorities include increasing the block rate to 10 blocks per second and implementing an upgrade to the consensus protocol, pending theoretical research results.
facts.context: Boosting block throughput and improving consensus directly affects scalability, transaction speed, and underlying protocol security.

facts.fact: Upcoming hard fork (HF) planned for the next week to fix a bug and reduce header size.
facts.context: Regular hard forks for bug fixes and optimizations keep the network secure and efficient, affecting node and miner operations.

facts.fact: Another hard fork is planned a few weeks later to implement the finalized monetary policy.
facts.context: Embedding monetary policy at the protocol level locks in economic parameters for the network.

facts.fact: Deployment of a block explorer is planned for the following week.
facts.context: A block explorer increases transparency and usability for users and developers interacting with the blockchain.

facts.fact: The network encourages stress testing for UTXO throughput, but advises waiting until the system is stable for at least two weeks after major changes.
facts.context: Stress testing helps identify potential scalability and stability issues under load after updates.

facts.fact: Kaspa is proposed to launch in "gamenet mode," which is a research-oriented experimental network rather than a standard mainnet cryptocurrency launch.
facts.context: Gamenet mode is designed to enable experimentation and attack simulations before transitioning to a commercial mainnet, allowing for robust testing of the protocol.

facts.fact: The initial Kaspa token will have a deliberately uncertain and semi-scarce monetary policy, making it unsuitable for commercialization and exchange listing.
facts.context: The intention is to discourage the token from becoming a tradable asset in early stages, focusing instead on drawing in hardcore crypto communities interested in research and experimentation.

facts.fact: Kaspa's platform is designed to be CPU/GPU mineable, with Ethash being suggested as a neutral mining algorithm candidate.
facts.context: CPU/GPU mining supports broader accessibility and participation in the early experimental network phase.

facts.fact: The initial gamenet launch will feature deliberately low security and low hashrate due to uncertain token scarcity and noncommercial nature.
facts.context: This environment is intended for experimentation, including attack simulations, rather than commercial use.

facts.fact: The gamenet's block rewards are designed to incentivize real-world attack simulations, such as reward-based and MEV-based reorgs, including selfish mining and miner extractable value (MEV) exploits.
facts.context: The network is intended as a live testbed for studying the effects and dynamics of advanced cryptoeconomic attacks in practice.

facts.fact: Gamenet 2.0 is proposed to include the development of an Ethereum bridge to simulate and practice MEV-reorgs, in order to test and demonstrate DAG consensus antifragility.
facts.context: Integrating with Ethereum enables the replication of real-world MEV dynamics and tests of the consensus algorithm's robustness.

facts.fact: Kaspa currently lacks EVM (Ethereum Virtual Machine) support.
facts.context: Without EVM support, smart contract compatibility and broader market integration are limited in the early stages.

facts.fact: The proposal calls for attracting research and developer groups to compete, collaborate, and experiment on the live gamenet system, for the study of consensus and attack vectors in practical settings.
facts.context: Engaging the R&D community helps generate credible insights into cryptoeconomic dynamics and stress-test the protocol.

facts.fact: There is a planned transition phase (cryptoeconomics phase 2) in which Kaspa will solidify its monetary policy, recover token scarcity, and compensate early participants as the network matures.
facts.context: As the network and community grow, sustainable economics and security are to be established for a commercial mainnet launch.

facts.fact: SPV (Simplified Payment Verification) sync mode based on multiplicative-hash UTXO-commitments is referenced as a technical approach.
facts.context: Multiplicative-hash UTXO-commitments are referenced as a basis for an SPV mode, suggesting a method for lightweight clients to securely sync with limited resources.

source.title: In which mayday mayday we are syncing about*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: Cryptocurrencies’ main technical advantages are predictable issuance and censorship resistance.
facts.context: Predictable issuance ensures transparent and scheduled supply, while censorship resistance ensures transactions cannot be arbitrarily blocked or controlled.

source.title: In which mayday mayday we are syncing about*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: The author asserts that the primary goal of consensus systems is facilitating agreement, not enforcing consistency.
facts.context: This suggests a philosophical and technical distinction in blockchain design priorities, potentially impacting consensus protocol implementations.

source.title: In which mayday mayday we are syncing about*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: Faster block times (block liveness) can reduce confirmation times for crypto payments, depending on the paradigm used for transaction authorization.
facts.context: If users or merchants wait for a certain number of blocks for transaction finality, then accelerating block production directly decreases the waiting time until a transaction is considered confirmed, improving usability for real-time payments.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: There are two paradigms for authorizing cryptocurrency payments: one based on the number of blocks elapsed (block-based confirmation), and another based on elapsed absolute time (time-based confirmation).
facts.context: The paradigm chosen affects whether faster block rates actually result in faster practical confirmation for users and merchants.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: The security budget in cryptocurrency mining (e.g., Bitcoin) refers to the revenue miners receive for securing the network, which is substantially smaller than the total value secured by the network.
facts.context: Discrepancy between the network’s value and its security budget can pose risks, as attackers might be able to spend more attacking the network than the total mining reward intended to prevent such attacks.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: In Bitcoin, if the security model is based on block confirmations, higher block rates can improve security against certain classes of attacks by reducing the window for attackers to outpace the honest chain.
facts.context: This affects how quickly transactions can be regarded as final and potentially deters short-term double-spend or reorganization attacks.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: If a time-based paradigm for confirmation is used (waiting a fixed amount of time rather than a number of blocks), faster block rates do not improve confirmation times.
facts.context: In such models, increasing block production has no direct impact on user-experienced transaction finality.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

facts.fact: The design trade-off between faster confirmation times and network resilience, decentralization, or social scalability is a recognized consideration in blockchain consensus protocol development.
facts.context: Protocol designers must balance user experience (UX) against core security and scalability objectives.

security.fact: The UTXO commitment obtained during network recovery matched the commitment in the latest block, specifically hash 710f27df423e63aa6cdb72b89ea5a06cffa399d66f167704455b5af59def8e20.
security.context: Validates that the DAG UTXO algebra remained correct, confirming integrity of the ledger after the recovery attempt.

security.fact: The network crash was attributed to a memory problem, not to an error in the DAG UTXO algebra.
security.context: Indicates that the underlying design is sound but susceptible to infrastructure issues, suggesting need for module architecture improvements.

security.fact: The initial gamenet launch will feature deliberately low security and low hashrate due to uncertain token scarcity and noncommercial nature.
security.context: This environment is intended for experimentation, including attack simulations, rather than commercial use.

security.fact: The gamenet's block rewards are designed to incentivize real-world attack simulations, such as reward-based and MEV-based reorgs, including selfish mining and miner extractable value (MEV) exploits.
security.context: The network is intended as a live testbed for studying the effects and dynamics of advanced cryptoeconomic attacks in practice.

security.fact: The security budget in cryptocurrency mining (e.g., Bitcoin) refers to the revenue miners receive for securing the network, which is substantially smaller than the total value secured by the network.
security.context: Discrepancy between the network’s value and its security budget can pose risks, as attackers might be able to spend more attacking the network than the total mining reward intended to prevent such attacks.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

security.fact: In Bitcoin, if the security model is based on block confirmations, higher block rates can improve security against certain classes of attacks by reducing the window for attackers to outpace the honest chain.
security.context: This affects how quickly transactions can be regarded as final and potentially deters short-term double-spend or reorganization attacks.

source.title: In which I have no patience to wait ’til by and by*
source.author: Yonatan Sompolinsky

development.fact: The timeline and completion of DAGKNIGHT integration on Kaspa are not strictly dependent on grant approval: the protocol authors intend to implement it regardless, but formal grant funding would accelerate development.
development.context: If the grant is not approved by the community, progress on DAGKNIGHT may be slower or completed on a non-specific timeline, potentially affecting upgrade timing.

development.fact: Further research is necessary to determine the optimal blocks-per-second for DK, as increasing block rates may widen the DAG and increase block header size, potentially offsetting confirmation time improvements.
development.context: Tuning block rates is critical for network performance and efficiency.

development.fact: The current DK pseudocode is highly inefficient and must be refined for real-world implementation, focusing on devising efficient algorithms.
development.context: Practical deployment requires the protocol to be computationally and resource efficient.

development.fact: The DK protocol must be adapted to manage cryptocurrency-specific requirements such as minting regulation, difficulty control, and pruning, which require a responsive synchronous protocol, instead of DK’s current partially synchronous operation mode.
development.context: Without these adaptations, DK cannot be deployed as a working consensus mechanism for cryptocurrencies like Kaspa.

development.fact: Completing DK’s formal proof, paper for peer-review, and efficient implementation are prerequisites before the protocol is considered for inclusion in Kaspa.
development.context: Academic scrutiny and technical readiness are essential before any consensus upgrade.

development.fact: One of Kaspa’s core developers, Michael Sutton, proposed refactoring the Kaspad full-node codebase and rewriting it in Rust to significantly enhance performance.
development.context: Transitioning to Rust is expected to improve modularity, code legibility, and potentially order-of-magnitude performance increases for Kaspa nodes.

development.fact: The current Kaspad codebase is an adaptation of the Bitcoin client btcd and is written in Golang.
development.context: The inherited structure leads to technical debt and code complexity, making contributions difficult for new developers.

development.fact: The proposed refactor aims to make the codebase more modular and easier to understand, beyond just improving performance.
development.context: Improved structure and readability can enhance community contribution and the maintainability of the project.

development.fact: A rebase of Kaspa is planned, which will be cosmetic only (a renaming/altering of representation) and will not affect user balances or proportional ownership.
development.context: Users' percentage ownership of total or circulating supply will remain unchanged after the rebase.

development.fact: Near-term development priorities include increasing the block rate to 10 blocks per second and implementing an upgrade to the consensus protocol, pending theoretical research results.
development.context: Boosting block throughput and improving consensus directly affects scalability, transaction speed, and underlying protocol security.

development.fact: Kaspa is proposed to launch in "gamenet mode," which is a research-oriented experimental network rather than a standard mainnet cryptocurrency launch.
development.context: Gamenet mode is designed to enable experimentation and attack simulations before transitioning to a commercial mainnet, allowing for robust testing of the protocol.

development.fact: Gamenet 2.0 is proposed to include the development of an Ethereum bridge to simulate and practice MEV-reorgs, in order to test and demonstrate DAG consensus antifragility.
development.context: Integrating with Ethereum enables the replication of real-world MEV dynamics and tests of the consensus algorithm's robustness.
